frameDefinitions: A Wearer removes an item of Clothing from a Body_location (the part of the body that the Clothing is prototypically worn on.)

A Theme changes location with respect to a salient location, which can be expressed by a Source, Path, Goal, Area, Direction, Path_shape, or Distance, as shown in the examples below: ''  'Start your ascent from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.'
A Self_mover intentionally moves in a Directionon a Path relative to landmark that is neither the Source nor the Goal of the overall motion.
Some entity (Theme) starts out in one place (Source) and ends up in some other place (Goal), having covered some space between the two (Path).
An event or state (here termed an Eventuality) or time-Period is described in terms of the Degree to which its duration diverges from a standard.
The words in this frame describe the 'fictive' motion of a stationary Road.
frameExamples: Walking on sand is better if you <t>take</t> <t>off</t> your shoes. INI
Start your <t>ascent</t> from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.
Ambrose Powell <t>forded</t> over on one horse, and we drove the others after him.
That kite you see just to the right of his head was <t>moving</t> around pretty fast but the camera seemed to catch it ok.
After a <t>lengthy</t> discussion with the Foreign Minister, Mr. Qian Qichen, they met the Prime Minister.
The long mountain road <t>meandered</t> through the woods.
listRoleDefinitions: The individual who begins the action wearing the <fen>Clothing</fen> and ends the action without it.
The item that the <fen>Wearer</fen> is initially wearing but then removes.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which a <fen>Wearer</fen> undresses.
The location at which the <fen>Wearer</fen> undresses an item of <fen>Clothing</fen>.

This is the object which moves. In many sentences this role will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this role is not <ment>required</ment> to be an animate mover, so it is different from Self_mover.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> (see below) expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, including directional expressions:
Any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element Goal.
Any expression which characterizes the extent of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Distance</fen>.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Theme</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
This is a sentient being or a vehicle steered by a sentient being which moves.
Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, excluding directional expressions:
Any expression which indicates where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Self_mover</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Self_mover</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location. Note that it is not necessarily a self-mover.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The <fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels  or to a landmark by which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up in.
<fen>Area</fen> identifies the setting in which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s movement takes place without a specified <fen>Path</fen>.
<fen>Distance</fen> is any expression which characterizes the extent of the Motion.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the Protagonist, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area in which a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>) occurs.

A situation, action or event whose duration is being described.  The Eventuality occurs as the External Argument if the adjective is used predicatively, or as the modified noun if the adjective is used attributively: <fex name='Eventuality'>The lecture</fex> was <t>short</t>. We had a <t>lengthy</t> <fex name='Eventuality'>conversation</fex>.

Sometimes these adjectives describe simply a period of time, rather than an event or state.  The Period almost invariably occurs as the modified noun with an attributive adjective: We waited for only a <t>short</t> <fex name='Period'>time</fex>. Use of the drug over a <t>lengthy</t> <fex name='Period'>period</fex> can cause memory loss.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the <fen>Road</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The trajectory that would be followed by one moving on the <fen>Road</fen>.
Any expression which tells where the fictive mover travelling along a <fen>Road</fen> would end up.

A physical path that a virtual moving entity can be imagined to travel along.
<fex name='Road'>The bike trail</fex> <t>zigzagged</t> through the woods.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> along the <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which a 'fictive' mover would travel along a <fen>Road</fen>.

The time when the fictive motion takes place.  This may describe the time when the <fen>Road</fen> or a particular piece of the <fen>Road</fen> existed, or it may implicitly describe the time when an actual motion event occurred on the <fen>Road</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The suspects</fex> had to strip publically and endure several blasts from a firehose.
<fex>Kim</fex> crossed through the woods.
The cat crossed the street <fex>from her yard</fex>.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children hopped <fex>into the neighbor's yard</fex>.
I leaped <fex>twenty feet</fex> before slipping and falling.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
He circled downward <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The frogs jumped <fex>down</fex> through the meadow.
They crisscrossed the country <fex>in April</fex>.
<fex>We</fex> drive down dusty roads, forded through a stream, and tried to get up a mountainside on a rocky road.
We forded <fex>from the island</fex> to the mainland.
We decided to cut <fex>through the forest</fex>.
I'll cut across the Sahara desert <fex>up to Algeria and Morocco</fex>.
We followed the trail (which is well marked with cairns) and then cut <fex>west</fex> across a grassy meadow for about 1000 feet to the crest of  the nearby saddle lying below North Peak.
The Federal Army of the Potomac forded the river <fex>in August 1862</fex>.
The common brook is best forded <fex>south of the hut</fex>.
The explosion made <fex>me</fex> move in a hurry.
The policeman moved <fex>away from the door</fex>.
Jo moved <fex>past Dad</fex> into the hall.
The car moved <fex>into the slow lane</fex>.
Emily moved restlessly <fex>around the room</fex>.
The twig floated atop the water <fex>for about 100 yards</fex>.
A radioactive cloud drifted across Britain <fex>after the fire at the Windscale nuclear factory</fex>.
The Way descends <fex>from the City of the Peak</fex> through a dense forest.
Valencia angles <fex>across the number streets</fex>.
<fex>Where</fex> does Interstate 80 enter the city ?
The paths crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
The cavern descended <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The pass dips <fex>down</fex> about 2000 feet, and then <fex>back up</fex> again.
<fex>Thousands of years ago</fex>, the Roman roads criss-crossed this landscape.
<fex>In the mountains</fex>, Highway 60 winds and swerves a lot, so we lost a couple of hours from my estimate.
